instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message:
So I've isolated the short on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> to <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 4 (Pulled <CAPACITOR>C1532</CAPACITOR>, 1533, 1531, 1910 and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> to confirm none of those were causing the short). 

Apart from making sure that I pull <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> from an identical board (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>), is there anything else I need to do before and after swapping the chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message:
Buy new PCH.
Is not expensive and easy to find real new.
After changed it, you need to clean ME region in BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message: Oh wow. Thanks. Thought I had to pull one from an identical board. Awesome will just buy one and save me the trouble and time. Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message: Unfortunately I can?t find any locally. All that I found were overseas.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U1100</CHIP>, refreshed EFI will clean ME. Boot powers up with fan spin but never boots. The cpu is cold. I noticed the CPU gets warm when I the medusa connected for the flashing of the chip. What signals from <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> would suggest I check to confirm this is work as it should?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message:
Try full known good BIOS.
Main BIOS could be corrupted; in such case cleaning original ME doesn't help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message:
Used a known good BIOS with the same result. Decided to check around the chip, and found pin 427 <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> @ 1.8 instead of 3.3. Resistance reading is 8k on defective chip and 19k to ground. The resistance of the resistor was also 8k on the bad board and 100k on a good board.

Ordered replacement chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> again, now the board won't power up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>. 

<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> - 0

Is it possible <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> from <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> could be the issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts (drop pulse) when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> should be always high, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> does react to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> trigger. Goes from 3.3 to 0.12

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message: So after reheating the <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> chip to make sure all solders connections were made, now <SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> cycles from 0.082 to 3.3. Even <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> cycles too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Short on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> Pin 41
threads.message:
Bad solders, or bad chip.
Can also be damaged board now...
